column5:
Hey! Iâ€™m doing a lot better the past two weeks actually, Iâ€™ve stopped a lot of body checking and I think thatâ€™s reduced a lot of anxiety. 

Thank you for sharing and reminding me that everything Iâ€™m experiencing is normal and a process that everyone else has to go through as well. I hope youâ€™re doing well in recovery as well and I super appreciate this comment! â¤ï¸

Youâ€™re doing a great job! It can be really hard and scary but youâ€™re doing things like eating even if you have no appetite, distracting yourself, an just plain not going back to old behaviors. I hope you feel better soon, but just know that youâ€™re doing amazing.

I think your problem lies not with how much food you want but the purging behaviors that follow. What do you fix? The restriction and the purging.

For me, I found the food isnâ€™t the problemâ€”no matter how much I eat, whether itâ€™s a little or a lot, my ED tells me to restrict in one way or another. When I ate fear foods before, Iâ€™d purge, and then not touch them for weeks or months while actively restricting to the point I was severely underweight and even eating a single cookie caused me to purge.

If youâ€™ve been watching a lot of recovery videos Iâ€™m sure you know about extreme hunger, and how itâ€™s absolutely normal and necessary (for most, as roughly 75% experience it) for your body to repair itself. but what you might feel like is a lie or that youâ€™ll be exempt from is that it WILL end when you continue to eat as much as your body wants. I cannot tell you how badly I wanted to purge and restrict that very first day of recovery, as the exact second I put food into my mouth the extreme hunger hit me like a brick wall and I could not stop eating. 7 weeks later, I still experience it every once in awhile but itâ€™s not nearly as intense. I still eat a lot, but not as much. It DOES get better.

And honestly, I canâ€™t tell you how I didnâ€™t revert back to purging and restricting, because thatâ€™s all my anorexic brain was telling me to do. I just... did it. And it was fucking hard, it is STILL hard. But you just do it, I guess. I had to just decide that I needed to give myself some tough love and say, â€œboohoo, eat the fucking cupcakeâ€”you can cry about it but youâ€™re still gonna fucking eat it.â€ But itâ€™s also about being compassionate and tending to that inner child. When I wanna restrict, I ask myself whatâ€™s triggered me, and then remind myself itâ€™s not my fault and Iâ€™m safe and we use words to express our pain rather than inflicting more pain onto our bodies.

I donâ€™t have a therapist or a nutritionist and therefore I donâ€™t follow a meal plan, I just eat what I want when I want, even if I end up crying while doing it (because I do, a lot), but recovery is unique to everyone. Find a therapist and nutritionist if you genuinely think you need one. If you donâ€™t want to follow a meal plan that leaves you hungry, then go all in and every time you want to purge, think about whyâ€”because itâ€™s never really about the food in a direct sense.

Welp, that was a total mess of a reply but I do hope it made sense.
Ugh I donâ€™t have a blender! ğŸ˜­ Iâ€™ve actually REALLY been craving smoothies and bowls lately though so I might just go out and buy one, lmao. Especially because milkshakes.

Tbh you probably havenâ€™t actually gained to your set point and the majority of said weight is probably water retention, food in the stomach, and, well, shit. Which can easily contribute to like, 10-16 lbs alone.

Iâ€™m also following an all in approach to recovery for almost 2 months now, from a very low BMI. Idk how much I weigh now, but I know Iâ€™m still retaining a good amount of water and I bloat like crazy after each meal because my digestion is still fixing itself. I have an *idea* of what my set point is but due to restriction I might have caused it to be a higher number and thatâ€™s just something I will have to live with and accept as a possibilityâ€”and so should you. If youâ€™re still experiencing physical and mental extreme hunger it means youâ€™re body is still doing repairs, especially if you havenâ€™t gotten your period back, and that you arenâ€™t at your set point. I [personally] think 2.5 months is a bit early to have even gained all the weight you needed to gain, especially when you consider that it takes A LOT of food to gain anyway.

Just keep eating tbh, I know it sucks but if youâ€™re still mentally and physically extreme hunger, the BEST thing for you to do is to listen to it. I still have extreme hunger a lot of days so youâ€™re definitely not alone in it.
Still deserve recovery, fight meeeee ğŸ¤—

SO MUCH THIS.

Especially when you donâ€™t tick all the stereotypical eating disorder boxes. Especially when you have atypical anorexia (which is STILL anorexia and the â€œatypicalâ€ is actually more common). Especially when youâ€™re not severely underweight and maybe â€œoverweight.â€ Especially without a medical diagnosis. I was just as sick at what was deemed as a healthy weight as I was when I was extremely underweight.

One of my favorite quotes is, â€œsociety says no to anorexia but yes to anorexic bodies.â€ Or course, this applies to all eating disorders but its really fucking unfortunate how we deem our suffering as less than because someone with the same eating disorder is thinner than we are or because society says itâ€™s our fault for having no self control (in the case of BED, for example).
Walking fast lessens my anxiety about food and gives me validation to eat which isnâ€™t healthy ğŸ¤·ğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸
Okay but seriously, Iâ€™ve always had bony hands and feet and a super slender neck and I was terrified Iâ€™d lose that when first started to really recovery. ğŸ¤¦ğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸

Honestly you canâ€™t really distinguish them without gaining weight. Iâ€™ve gained quite a bit over the past 6 weeks going all in and I STILL cannot tell when Iâ€™m full or even actually physically hungry. Thatâ€™s why eating at least 3 meals and 2-3 snacks are crucial.

Honestly, at first I thought that it was just a habit. I first thought I started out bulimic, but I was just anorexic and purged when I ate â€œbadâ€ foods or felt like I ate too much (which was never the case). I also have OCD which tends to manifest in my ED as a form of control but I didnâ€™t know that when I was first diagnosed and thought I learned to work through my OCD through therapy and self help books. Which was true, except that after that my ED just seemed to flare the fuck up and suddenly I had all these new rules and foods I couldnâ€™t eat. I used to think it was such bullshit to assume that any and all EDs stem from some psychological trauma (thanks, Brain Over Binge) because even when I thought I was happy or â€œbetterâ€ I was still severely restricting and sometimes when Iâ€™d â€œeat too muchâ€ Iâ€™d purge without any sort of trauma attached to it. And then one day it just fucking clicked for me and I knew that the only way Iâ€™d recover and maintain recovery was if I resolved that trauma (work in progress, btw lol). 

My trauma was food scarcity and insecurities that started as late as 4 years old, as well as extremely poor body image and a mother with a history of anorexia, which made me 10 times more likely to develop an eating disorder. My fear around eating too much due to food scarcity and eating â€œhealthy foodsâ€ and over exercising was a learned response; but it was also a way to cope with all of my other negative emotions. When I would get really upset, I wouldnâ€™t eat or eat far lessâ€”because I canâ€™t control anything but my diet and thatâ€™s something I REALLY clung to without even realizing it. Like, you canâ€™t feel emotional pain, let alone emotions at all, if youâ€™re too busy counting calories. And the really fucked up thing is that idk when exactly I developed my ED because restriction has literally been all Iâ€™ve ever known.

It really depends, i just jumped all in and started eating at least my minimums from day one because the â€œgoing slowâ€ approach simply wasnâ€™t working for me and I was finding any and all ways to restrict and compensate. That said, I was severely restricting and compensating my eating with over exercising and activity in general so I could have easily developed refeeding syndrome. Therefore, just be careful.

Rule of thumb that Iâ€™ve read is if youâ€™ve been eating more than 1000 cals a day consistently for 2 weeks (not including exercise or other physical activity), then you can dive right in. If youâ€™re below that, itâ€™s recommended you gradually bump calories up by 200-300 every few days til you reach 2000 and then start eating minimums without worrying about refeeding syndrome.

Also, I follow HDRM which says my minimums for height and age are pretty high so dont compare. But I do suggest that once you do begin to meet minimums remember that thatâ€™s exactly what they areâ€”minimums. Youâ€™re allowed, and actually expected to eat a lot more than that if youâ€™re hungry (mentally and physically).

I always eat more on days Iâ€™m a bit more active (hyper metabolism is real lmao), and I made sure to eat super caloric dense food yesterday but omg today the mental extreme hunger was crazy hahah

Thatâ€™s actually not trueâ€”BED is often tied to emotions and has nothing to do with hunger, if youâ€™re â€œbingingâ€ in recovery from a restrictive ED then your body needs that food because itâ€™s fucking hungry. When you restrict you put yourself into an energy deficit and youâ€™re going to have to make up for that PLUS the energy you already need in a day. So if you restrict and over exercise for years, thatâ€™s A LOT of calories to make up. Thatâ€™s why we experience extreme hunger. Recovery binge eating is a natural bodily response to starvation or semi-starvation, and it is even seen in animals who were deprived of food as well.

I can actually go back to photos from 1-2 years years ago when I was near the weight my body always seems to go back to when I thought I was â€œfatâ€ and actually see how that was just a distortion.

Basically, I only saw through my own dysmorphia in recovery, but I canâ€™t see it with my current bodyâ€”not when I was a â€œhealthyâ€ weight, not underweight and not in recovery. I literally hate my recovering body, but Iâ€™m also like, I hated my body before that sooo really whatâ€™s different?

I know thatâ€™s not THAT helpful but it does kind of remind me that I probably donâ€™t look as bad as I think I do.

Also in recovery from an eating disorder. I donâ€™t track but I make sure I have at least three meals and three snacks, and listen to hunger cues, which some days Iâ€™ve not show up as mental hunger (i.e., thinking a lot about food = hunger). Iâ€™m a very rigid person, so it was hard for me to give up certain â€œrulesâ€ and protocols, so what I found useful when getting rid of unhealthy ones for healthy onesâ€”such as, creating times I eat, whether or not Iâ€™m physically hungry. Idk how well this might work out so if recovery, but considering that so many people are stressed and have a loss of appetite during this pandemic, I think something similar might be a good guideline for a lot of people who just arenâ€™t hungry but know they need to eat.

I think I was just under or above 100 lbs in 5th grade, and my lowest weight while actively restricting (this past March) was under 100 lbs 

Kind of funny, considering I was actually a pretty chubby kid once i hit that weight, and gained a bit more than half that up until I was 15.

Oh yeah itâ€™s definitely edema, Iâ€™m only one month into recovery. Itâ€™s just really traumatic since I was pretty underweight and Iâ€™ve gained AT LEAST 20-30 lbs already. I know itâ€™s impossible to have gained that much in actual body weight alone... but it feels like it and it sucks.

Youâ€™re absolutely right about the resting as well, the swelling is a lot more persistent following days Iâ€™m on my feet a lot.

I mean it could be an intolerance from restricting but I donâ€™t have any allergies or things like lactose intolerance. Mainly I avoided carbs, milk and sugar.

I also drink a lot of water, not nearly as much as before I started recovery, but an adequate amount. Itâ€™s just annoying and itâ€™s really fucking with my already rock bottom self esteem.

Im glad it helped!

I have experienced a lot of improvements in health actually. I do have significantly less joint pain, especially in my knees. I never necessarily had chest pains from walking or exercising but I would get them randomly and Iâ€™d also experience my heartbeat getting so slow that it would leave me gasping for air it was so weird and scary, especially because I didnâ€™t link it to my ED until I started recovery. Honestly A LOT of my issues have been ED relatedâ€”my sleep, super dry and brittle hair/nails, bathroom problems. So much shit.

I also reallyyyy feel you about overshooting, but I think itâ€™s unavoidable, which is really shitty but if itâ€™s necessary then itâ€™s necessary. Iâ€™ve also gained a lot very quicklyâ€”at least I feel like it, Iâ€™m sure the majority of it is water weight still. What helps me with the weight gain is remembering that the only thing that convinced me to really accept that I was anorexic was COVID19 and the fact that if I caught it and lost anywhere near what others were reporting when I was already 95 lbs soaking wet, on top of the other symptoms, it would have fucking killed me no doubt. So at this point Iâ€™m like, okay I can either gain weight and be a little heavier for awhile before it drops back down or I can relapse die, thereâ€™s really no in between.

Tabitha Farrar is amazing too! Every time I feel super shorty I go to her YouTube or read her blogs. Itâ€™s super scary but Youâ€™re doing great! If you ever need to talk about everything more feel free to DM me ğŸ™‚

Your numbers are almost identical to mine, except Iâ€™m an inch shorter. I was consuming anywhere between 6,000-10,000 calories the first week I started recovery. Now Iâ€™m eating pretty â€œnormallyâ€ in terms of feeling full and Iâ€™m no longer eating a million pb&jâ€™s, a whole box of cereal with milk and poptart after poptart and averaging like 3000 calories at least (which is my minimum). Usually though, Iâ€™ll have one or two days a week where no matter what or how much I eat, I am still fucking hungry and I end up eating all day to the point Iâ€™m shaking if I donâ€™t. Itâ€™s insane.

Obviously not on a meal plan and just eating whatever the hell I want, because I basically didnâ€™t eat anything outside of a small list of safe foods. I donâ€™t expect the extreme hunger to go away entirely until Iâ€™m around a normal-ish weight, but it also wouldnâ€™t surprise me if it stuck around for a year (just because Iâ€™ve read thatâ€™s common).

As for â€œproper meals,â€ Iâ€™ve fallen into the habit naturally of eating meals Iâ€™ve prepared like pasta or burgers, whereas before I was having cookies and icecream every hour of the day. so I wouldnâ€™t worry about that too much, since giving into my cravings whenever and for how many, I just donâ€™t crave that stuff as much and I actually look forward to things outside of pure junk food and sugar. At first I was eating literally every 30-60 minutes and I mean EATING. Now I have my three meals and three snacks, and then some if Iâ€™m hungry and Iâ€™m expected to be because thatâ€™s normal. The three meals and three snacks are minimums, if youâ€™re hungry beyond that thatâ€™s fineâ€”stop worrying about eating the right portions or eating normal because your body is fucking hungry and itâ€™s gonna be hungry for a long time, and you still might be eating more after you hit your healthy weight (so Iâ€™ve read). If you just listen to your body, youâ€™re not gonna be hungry forever and naturally youâ€™ll fall into a routine that works for you.
... bottom right one pissed me tf off because it is deadass me, fucking RIP

Tbh I think it was because I was a chubby kid and I was consistently made fun of for it until I turned 15 and my weight naturally dropped and evened out. But during that time, my friends would always say â€œyouâ€™re not fat!â€ (which I know is shitty because so what if I was?) when I knew I was a lot heavier than them and it kind of made me cynical and suspicious when it came to being complimented. I guess that same reaction rolled over into my thinner years and later my ED years.

For me, the hunger is only really intense in the mornings, especially if I didnâ€™t wake up to eat during the night (itâ€™s still early in recovery for me). I think itâ€™s because Usually I try to only wait 3 hours max to eat, but Iâ€™ll go anywhere between 4-9 hours without food from when I go to sleep to waking up the next morning. And at this point my body is no longer pumping me full of cortisol to give me energy and not die in a starved state. So anything beyond 3 hours and my body is like â€œomg noâ€ if that makes sense?

Also, I know I should listen to my hunger even if I JUST ate but sometimes i didnâ€™t bring enough snacks or whatever so Iâ€™m forced to push those boundaries a little bit. Usually I start to feel nauseated from hunger at around the 2.5-3 hour mark. Anything beyond that, EAPECIALLY if Iâ€™ve been on my feet for awhile, and itâ€™s game over lol.

I didnâ€™t really use it to determine progress, I just donâ€™t have any other clothes, you know? I knew from the start that Iâ€™d bloat like crazy and my clothes wouldnâ€™t fit, that was to be expected. But I didnâ€™t think Iâ€™d have a fucking crying fit over the clothes either. Itâ€™s just hard.

That said, Iâ€™m lucky I dont have a scale and Iâ€™ve been avoiding mirrors like the fucking plague hahah. I think doing a diary is a good idea too because itâ€™s about once a week I have a meltdown and a few times Iâ€™m just feeling a little depressed about it all. So I think thatâ€™ll help big time with recognizing and processing these intense emotions.

Youâ€™re right, I do know it.

Like when I was going to therapy for all of my other issues and then opened up about my anorexia a few years back it made me feel good to be â€œsick.â€ Like I was getting all this attention and people were checking in on me way more than when they didnâ€™t know I was struggling. It sounds fucked up but I liked the attention my eating disorder especially garnished from basically everyone in my life.

And itâ€™s fucking dumb now too because when my boyfriend says, â€œyou already look healthierâ€ I am fucking offended and it makes me want to revert back to restricting and purging. I feel like for me this is due to past trauma of not having parents who really gave me attention unless I was throwing tantrums or got hurt or whatever. So if Iâ€™m not sick anymore then I believe that no one is gonna worry about me and theyâ€™ll forget about and abandon me. Obviously this isnâ€™t true, but thatâ€™s what keeps going through my head.

Gonna have to disagree with you in terms of fat adaption energy for intense exercise like CrossFitâ€”if youâ€™re doing a ketogenic diet, things like weight lifting or jogging are far better because itâ€™s low intensity and donâ€™t rely heavily on carbohydrates for energy. Anything that requires short bursts of energy (such as CrossFit and HIIT) arenâ€™t great for people who rely on fat or ketones for energy because high-intensity exercise forces the body to shift to glycogen as fuel regardless of what your macronutrients are. I did CrossFit for two years before my ED and my coach wouldnâ€™t let us even touch the equipment until we understood proper form and the importance or properly fueling your body for the types of exercises we did.

That said, iâ€™m not necessarily saying that trying a certain â€œwoeâ€ is or isnâ€™t harmful, but when you have a history of eating disorders, I think itâ€™s worth really considering why youâ€™re doing it. I personally donâ€™t believe in keto, paleo, veganism, whatever else anymore because I just canâ€™t restrict like that on a regular basis and if youâ€™re gonna eat the cake anyway then whatâ€™s the point?

Thatâ€™s just my two cents though. I mean, I guess as long as youâ€™re mindful but just donâ€™t fool yourself at the end of the day, you know?

I said did keto for the same reasonsâ€” but in reality it was because it was the only thing that made me feel â€œsafeâ€ eating. I had no intention of losing weight on it either but my ED took control over that as well and soon I was severely underweight, terrified of carbohydrates and sugar and also excessively working out even though I *knew* the exercises I was doing required energy from carbs I wouldnâ€™t touch.

Agree with this 10000%. Keto and excessive exercise was what really caused my eating disorder to spiral and I even used the diet as an excuse to claim I was â€œrecoveringâ€ because it was the only way Iâ€™d eat. But restriction is not health or recovery. Especially doing something as intense as CrossFit, where you NEED loads of glycogen/energy to perform, which you simply donâ€™t get from severely restricting carbs.

Itâ€™s just part of the refeeding process. Firstly, your body isnâ€™t used to food so itâ€™s going to bloat a little with consistent feeding. Secondly, restriction causes dehydration and damage to your body so youâ€™re going to hold water to rehydrate you and also because itâ€™s easier to get the cells where they need to go to fix the damage, and usually the worst is your vital organs which happen to sit in your torso/stomach area; however long this persists depends on your consistency throughout recovery. Thirdly, your digestion is shot to shit so whatever you eat is going to sit in the stomach longer and ferment in order to pull as much nutrients as possible (this is what causes the gas which contributes to bloating).

Iâ€™ve done a lot of research to avoid getting stuck in quasi recovery again, and basically everything says that youâ€™re recovered when:
â€¢youâ€™re weight restored AND have your period back
â€¢you donâ€™t constantly think about food except when youâ€™re hungry
â€¢your hunger cues are back to normal and you know when youâ€™re hungry, full or sated and you eat intuitively without restriction.

As for oneâ€™s mental state, thatâ€™s a whole other part of recovery that often requires a therapist. In my case, Iâ€™ve always been able to work through my psychological issues myself so I just journal my emotions, etc. and try to process them in ways that I know work for me, such as CBT techniques, mindfulness, yadayada. That said, I think many people struggle with body image in general, let alone if they have an eating disorder. I donâ€™t think you need to â€œfeel goodâ€ about your body to consider yourself recovered, BUT I do think you have to feel a certain level of acceptance toward your recovered body. Self love does not equal loving your physical body (because it doesnâ€™t define your worth); self love is accepting the body you have and loving it for the things it does to keep us alive. According to many sources, about 75% of people with a restrictive ed will experience extreme hunger. The second day I started refeeding, I could. Not. Stop. Eating. I was so fucking full and yet still so hungry.

Some days itâ€™s more pronounced than others. Iâ€™ve realized that on days Iâ€™m more active (as in, running to the grocery store or cleaning my apartment), Iâ€™m insatiably hungry either that night or all throughout the next day. Also, I am overall extremely hungry in the evenings no matter what or how much I eat. I used to fast all throughout the day and then eat a minuscule amount of calories before bed, so my body just instinctively knows that food+nighttime leads to a famine so now that Iâ€™m eating, it wants any and all food since it doesnâ€™t know if there will be more the following day (shocker: there always is now).

I know it sucks and it can be scary but you have to understand that itâ€™s our bodyâ€™s response to starvation. We created a MASSIVE energy deficit. Say if you owe the bank $3000 and you only pay $1000 or less, the bankâ€™s gonna be pissed off and now youâ€™ll have to owe $3000 AND another $2000.l the next day. Now within a year youâ€™ll owe $728,000 because you kept throwing in $1000 a day but the debt keeps growing because it just isnâ€™t enough. So imagine that number, times the years of restriction (for me it was 6+ years). Thatâ€™s a lot of fucking food and your body doesnâ€™t believe there wonâ€™t be a famine again so itâ€™s going to want as much food as humanely possibleâ€”it doesnâ€™t care if youâ€™re nauseatingly full or scared shitless, it just wants food to survive. Iâ€™ve eaten far past the daily minimums most days since I started recoveryâ€”and thatâ€™s fine, we need it.

So if you listen to it and eat (mental hunger is also extreme hunger btw), it will eventually go away. For me, I simply found it easier to just say fuck it and enjoy the food rather than panic over the same food Iâ€™m going to have to eat regardless. Also keep in mind that your body is going to want calorie dense food that will offer quick energy; i.e., junk food. Itâ€™s easy for your fucked up digestion to pull nutrients from and your body burns it up quick to put towards healing your body and closing that deficit youâ€™ve created. Donâ€™t be afraid to eat like literal shit for awhile, itâ€™s literally going to save your life. I basically live off cookies, icecream, poptarts and French toast drenched in syrup. Just eat what you crave (not what you THINK is â€œhealthyâ€) and i promise it will eventually dissipate.
